name: Guru Hargobind Sahib Ji
birthPlace: Guru Ki Wadali, Amritsar District, Punjab
excerpt: Guru Hargobind Sahib Ji, the sixth Sikh Guru, transformed Sikhism by instilling martial spirit and integrating temporal and spiritual leadership. After Guru Arjan’s martyrdom, he adorned two swords symbolizing Miri and Piri, built the Akal Takht, fortified Sikh centers, and led the community in several battles to defend righteousness—setting the foundation for the Sikh warrior tradition.

quickStats.label: Main Sons
quickStats.value: Baba Gurditta, Baba Suraj Mal, Guru Tegh Bahadur

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Guru Hargobind Sahib Ji was born on 19 June 1595 at Guru Ki Wadali near Amritsar to Guru Arjan Dev Ji and Mata Ganga Ji. Under Baba Buddha Ji’s guidance, he learned both spiritual wisdom and martial arts from a young age.

biographySections.label: Becoming Guru and Initiation of Miri-Piri
biographySections.value: After Guru Arjan’s martyrdom in 1606, the eleven-year-old Hargobind was installed as Guru. He donned two swords, representing Miri (temporal power) and Piri (spiritual authority), initiating the tradition of Saint-Soldier in Sikhism.

biographySections.label: Militarization and Defense
biographySections.value: Guru Hargobind built up the Sikh community’s military strength, assembling a cavalry, acquiring arms, and establishing a regular battalion. He fortified Amritsar, built the Lohgarh fort, and asked Sikhs to provide not just financial but also military support.

biographySections.label: Akal Takht and Sovereignty
biographySections.value: In 1609, Guru Hargobind established the Akal Takht, directly facing the Harmandir Sahib (Golden Temple), to serve as the seat of Sikh temporal authority. Here, he held court and made decisions on both spiritual and worldly matters.

biographySections.label: Conflicts and Battles
biographySections.value: To defend the Sikh faith, Guru Hargobind led Sikhs in four major battles against the Mughal Empire. These were fought at Amritsar, Sri Hargobindpur, Gurusar, and Kartarpur, always with the intention to defend righteousness, not conquer territory.

biographySections.label: Imprisonment at Gwalior
biographySections.value: Guru Hargobind was imprisoned at Gwalior Fort for several years by Emperor Jahangir, but was eventually released along with 52 detained Hindu princes, earning him the title 'Bandi Chhor' (Liberator of Prisoners).

biographySections.label: Final Years and Succession
biographySections.value: In his later life, Guru Hargobind founded Kiratpur Sahib as a spiritual center. He continued to strengthen Sikh institutions until his passing in 1644. He appointed his grandson Guru Har Rai Ji as his successor.

spiritualLegacy.description: Guru Hargobind Sahib Ji fused the temporal and spiritual domains in Sikhism and redefined the Sikh identity as both saintly and sovereign. His concept of Miri-Piri laid the framework for a martial faith rooted in justice and compassion.
keyContributions: Introduced the dual concept of Miri (temporal) and Piri (spiritual) authority
Built the Akal Takht, cementing Sikh sovereign governance
Transformed Sikhs into a martial community prepared to defend truth
Refused to seize territory, emphasizing just war (Dharamyudh)
Liberated 52 Hindu princes from Gwalior Fort, earning the title Bandi Chhor

modernRelevance.description: Guru Hargobind Sahib Ji’s teachings inspire Sikh commitment to justice, community defense, and the enduring balance between spirituality and worldly responsibility.
contemporaryImpact: The Akal Takht remains Sikhism’s highest seat of temporal authority
Miri-Piri ideal shapes Sikh social activism and political engagement
Bandi Chhor Divas, commemorating the liberation of the 52 princes, is widely celebrated
Sikh martial tradition influences Sikh identity world-wide

achievements.title: Founded the Akal Takht
achievements.description: Established the temporal seat of Sikh authority facing the Harmandir Sahib.

achievements.title: Instituted Miri-Piri Dual Symbolism
achievements.description: Wore two swords during his investiture to signify joined temporal and spiritual authority.

achievements.title: Built Lohgarh Fort
achievements.description: Fortified Amritsar for the first time to defend against Mughal attacks.

achievements.title: Fought Four Major Battles
achievements.description: Defended the Sikh community against Mughal aggression at Amritsar, Hargobindpur, Gurusar, and Kartarpur.

achievements.title: Liberated 52 Princes (Bandi Chhor)
achievements.description: Secured the release of 52 Hindu princes from Mughal captivity while leaving Gwalior Fort.

quotes.translation: Become the master of both temporal and spiritual realms.

quotes.original: ਸੱਚ ਦੀ ਸੇਵਾ ਅਤੇ ਜੰਗ ਦੋਹਾਂ ਲਈ ਤਿਆਰ ਰਹੋ
quotes.transliteration: Sach dī sevā ate jang dohān la'ī tiār raho
quotes.translation: Be ever ready to serve the truth and fight for justice.

quotes.original: ਬੰਦੀ ਛੋੜ — ਮਨੁੱਖਤਾ ਨੂੰ ਅਜ਼ਾਦ ਕਰਵਾਉਣਾ ਸਭ ਤੋਂ ਵੱਡੀ ਸੇਵਾ ਹੈ।
quotes.transliteration: Bandī choṛ — manukhta nūṁ azād karvāuṇā sabh to vaddī sevā hai.
quotes.translation: To liberate humanity is the greatest service.
quotes.context: On liberating the 52 princes, Bandi Chhor Divas
quotes.source: Popular Sikh saying regarding Guru Hargobind Sahib Ji

historicalContext.period: Early to mid-17th century (Mughal Empire: Jahangir, Shah Jahan)
historicalContext.politicalSituation: Polarization and rising persecution after Guru Arjan’s execution; increased militarization under Guru Hargobind to defend Sikhs and others from Mughal oppression.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Growing assertion of Sikh identity, greater need for community self-defense, and transformation into a faith that merges spiritual with temporal interests.
historicalContext.significance: Guru Hargobind’s leadership reoriented Sikhism toward temporal self-determination and martial readiness while upholding its core spiritual values.
